posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked: good morning! I have doubts about how to use the trough bore encoder in its absolute mode in programming. Does anyone know how I can do this?

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Generally, you don’t program for that device directly, you access it through whatever it is wired to.  How do you have it wired? Directly to a sparkmax? To the rio? If so, what port?

posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked: I connect directly to Roborio at input 5

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: “Input 5” isn’t particularly helpful.  Do you mean “DIO 5”?

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
You can find docs on how to wire it here: Application Examples | REV Crossover Products .   Sounds like you probably wired it correctly, so we’ll move on to software.

You’ll notice those docs mention the DutyCycleEncoder.  So if we switch to the wpilib docs, we can find how to use that class: Encoders - Software — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

link_counts.title: Encoders - Software — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: You’re going to need to be MUCH more specific.

posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked: it even sends values, however, they vary between 0 and 1, varying between increasing and decreasing

posts.name: Miguel Ramos
posts.cooked:
The absolute mode of the encoder is used to measure the angles of an arm, for example, so its value is always between 0 and 1, and will not exceed that like the relative encoder

for what purpose are you using the through bore?

posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked: yes I know. I’m just testing it on one of my team’s projects for the season and the intention is to actually use absolute

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: How would you like it to behave? Describe what value you want it to report at 0 rotations, half a rotation, just below 1 rotation and just above 1 rotation. What value is it reporting now for each of those cases?

posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked: I wanted to test it by increasing it from 0 to 360 (only 1 turn), but it only varies from 0 to 1 degrees

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: Multiply the output value by 360 degrees

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Read through the wpilib docs again.  Theres a yellow box that will explain why you’re seeing what you’re seeing, and an entire section on how you can change it.

posts.name: Sylvain D.
posts.cooked:
Edit: Using sparkmax there is way to apply a conversion factor. You might have to do a similar trick by multiplying the value…

(on Sparkmax) you can set the conversion factor using this:

this will return values between 0 and 360. By default I returns values between 0.0 and 1.0 rotation.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: OP isn’t wiring it to a Spark* controller, so that configuration isn’t available
